French_1748_ch1.translated_title: On the subject of this Book.
French_1748_ch1.original_text: Cette matière est d'une grande étendue. Dans cette foule d'idées qui se présentent à mon esprit, je serai plus attentif à l'ordre des choses qu'aux choses mêmes ; il faut que j'écarte à droite et à gauche, que je perce, et que je me fasse jour.
French_1748_ch1.translation: This subject is very extensive. In this crowd of ideas that present themselves to my mind, I'll be more attentive to the order of things than to the things themselves; I must push aside to the right and to the left, pierce through, and make myself visible.

French_1748_ch2.original_title: Combien pour les meilleures Loix il est nécessaire que les esprits soient préparés.
French_1748_ch2.translated_title: How necessary it is for minds to be prepared for the best Laws.
French_1748_ch2.original_text:
Rien ne parut plus insupportable aux Germains (*Il coupoit la langue aux Avocats, et disoit : Vipère, cesse de siffler. Tacite.) que le tribunal de Varus. Celui que Justinien érigea chez les Laziens pour faire le procès au meurtrier de leur Roi, leur parut une chose horrible et barbare. Mithridate haranguant contre les Romains, leur reproche surtout les formalités de leur Justice. Les Parthes ne purent supporter ce Roi, qui ayant été élevé à Rome se rendit affable et accessible à tout le monde. La liberté même à paru insupportable à des peuples qui n'étoient pas accoutumés à en jouir, Cest ainsi qu'un air pur est quelquefois nuisible à ceux qui ont vécu dans des païs marécageux.
Un Venitien nommé Balbi, étant au Pégu, fut introduit chez le Roi. Quand celui-ci apprit qu'il n'y avoit point de Roi à Venise, il fit un si grand éclat de tire, qu'une toux le prit, et qu'il eut beaucoup de peine à parler à ses Courtisans. Quel est le Législateur qui pourroit proposer le Gouvernement populaire à des peuples pareils?
French_1748_ch2.translation:
Nothing seemed more unbearable to the Germans (*He cut out the tongue of the Lawyers, and said: Viper, stop hissing. Tacitus) than the court of Varus. The tribunal that Justinian set up among the Lazians to try the murderer of their King seemed to them a horrible and barbaric thing. Mithridate, haranguing against the Romans, reproached them above all for the formalities of their justice system. The Parthians couldn't stand this King, who, having been raised in Rome, made himself affable and accessible to everyone. Freedom itself seemed unbearable to people who were not accustomed to enjoying it, just as pure air is sometimes harmful to those who have lived in marshy lands.
A Venetian named Balbi, while in Pegu, was introduced to the King. When the King learned that there was no King in Venice, he burst into such a fit of laughter that a cough took hold of him, and he found it very difficult to speak to his courtiers. What legislator could propose popular government to such peoples?

French_1748_ch3.original_text:
Il y a deux fortes de Tyrannie; une réelle, qui consiste dans la violence du Gouvernement ; et une d’opinion, qui se fait sentir lorsque ceux qui gouvernent établissent des choses qui choquent la manière de penser d’une Nation.
Dion dit qu’Auguste voulut se faire appeller Romulus ; mais qu’ayant appris que le peuple craignoit qu’il ne voulut se faire Roi, il changea de dessein. Les premiers Romains ne vouloient point de Roi, parce qu’ils n’en pouvoient souffrir la puissance: Les Romains d’alors ne vouloient point de Roi, pour n’en point souffrir les manières. Car quoique César, les Triumvirs, Auguste, fussent de véritables Rois, ils avoient gardé tout l’extérieur de l’egalité, et leur vie privée contenoit une espèce d’opposition avec le faste des Rois d’alors, et quand ils ne vouloient point de Roi, cela signifioit qu’ils vouloient garder leurs manières, et ne pas prendre celles des peuples d’Afrique et d'Orient.
Dion nous dit que le peuple Romain étoit indigné contre Auguste, à cause de certaines Loix trop dures qu’il avoit faites: mais que si-tôt qu’il eut fait revenir le Comédien Pylade que les factions avoient chassé de la ville, le mécontentement cessa. Un Peuple pareil sentoit plus vivement la tyrannie lorsqu'on chassoit un baladin, que lors qu'on lui ôtoit toutes ses Loix.
French_1748_ch3.translation:
There are two types of Tyranny: a real one, which consists in the violence of Government; and one of opinion, which is felt when those who govern establish things that offend a Nation's way of thinking.
Dion says that Augustus wanted to be called Romulus, but having learned that the people feared that he wanted to make himself King, he changed his mind. The first Romans did not want a King, because they could not bear the power of one: the Romans of the time did not want a King, because they could not bear the manners of one. For although Caesar, the Triumvirs and Augustus were true kings, they had retained all the outward egalitarianism, and their private life contained a kind of opposition to the pomp of the kings of the time, and when they wanted no king, it meant that they wanted to keep their manners, and not take on those of the peoples of Africa and the East.
Dion tells us that the Roman people were indignant against Augustus, because of certain laws he had made that were too harsh: but as soon as he had brought back the actor Pylades, whom the factions had driven out of the city, the discontent ceased. Such a people felt tyranny more keenly when a balladeer was driven out, than when all their laws were taken away.

French_1748_ch4.original_title: Ce que c’est que l’esprit général.
French_1748_ch4.original_text:
Plusieurs choses gouvernent les hommes, le Climat, la Religion, les Loix, les maximes du Gouvernement, les exemples des choses passées, les mœurs, les manières ; d'où il le forme un esprit général qui en résulte.
A mesure que dans chaque Nation une de ces causes agit avec plus de force, les autres lui cèdent d'autant. La Nature et le climat dominent presque seuls sur les Sauvages ; les manières gouvernent les Chinois ; les Loix tyrannisent le Japon ; les mœurs donnoient autrefois le ton dans Lacédémone ; les maximes du Gouvernement et les mœurs anciennes le donnoient dans Rome.
French_1748_ch4.translation:
Several things govern men: climate, religion, laws, maxims of government, examples from the past, morals and manners.
As one of these causes becomes stronger in each nation, the others give way to it. Nature and climate almost single-handedly dominate the savages; manners govern the Chinese; laws tyrannize Japan; manners once set the tone in Lacedemonia; the maxims of government and ancient mores set the tone in Rome.

French_1748_ch5.original_title: Combien il faut être attentif à ne point changer l'esprit général d'une Nation.
French_1748_ch5.translated_title: How careful we must be not to change the general spirit of a nation.
French_1748_ch5.original_text:
S'il y avoit dans le monde une Nation qui eût une humeur sociable, une ouverture de cœur, une joye dans la vie, un goût, une facilité à communiquer ses pensées ; qui sut vive, agréable, enjouée, quelquefois imprudente, souvent indiscrète ; et qui eut avec cela du courage, de la générosité, de la franchise, un certain point d'honneur ; il ne faudroit point chercher à gêner par des loix ses manières, pour ne point gêner ses vertus. Si en général le caractère est bon, qu'importe de quelques défauts qui s'y trouvent?
On y pourroit contenir les femmes, faire des Loix pour corriger leurs mœurs, et borner leur luxe : mais qui sçait si on n'y perdroit pas un certain goût qui seroit la source des richesses de la Nation, et une politesse qui attire chez elle les étrangers ?
C'est au Législateur à suivre l'esprit de la Nation, lorsqu'il n'est pas contraire aux principes du Gouvernement ; car nous ne saisons rien de mieux que ce que nous saisons librement et en suivant nôtre génie naturel.
Qu'on donne un esprit de pédanterie à une Nation naturellement gaye, l'Etat n'y gagnera rien, ni pour le dedans ni pour le dehors. Laissez-lui faire les choses frivoles sérieusement, et gayement les choses sérieuses.
French_1748_ch5.translation:
If there were a nation in the world with a sociable temperament, an open heart, a joy in life, a taste for and facility in communicating their thoughts; who knew how to be lively, pleasant, playful, sometimes imprudent, often indiscreet; and who had courage, generosity, frankness, a certain point of honor; we should not seek to hinder their manners by laws, so as not to hinder their virtues. If the character in general is good, what does it matter if there are a few faults?
We could restrain women, make laws to correct their morals, and limit their luxury: but who knows if we wouldn't lose a certain taste that would be the source of the Nation's wealth, and a politeness that attracts foreigners to the country?
It is up to the Legislator to follow the spirit of the Nation, when it is not contrary to the principles of the Government; for we do not season anything better than what we season freely and following our natural genius.
Let a pedantic spirit be given to a naturally gay Nation, and the State will gain nothing, either internally or externally. Let them take frivolous things seriously, and serious things gayly.

French_1748_ch6.original_title: Qu'il ne faut pas tout corriger.
French_1748_ch6.translated_title: That not everything needs to be corrected.
French_1748_ch6.original_text:
Qu'on nous laisse comme nous sommes, disoit un Gentilhomme d'une Nation qui ressemble beaucoup à celle dont nous venons de donner une idée. La Nature répare tout. Elle nous a donné une vivacité capable d'offenser et propre à nous faire manquer à tous les égards ; cette même vivacité est corrigée parla politesse qu'elle nous procure, en nous inspirant du goût pour le monde et surtout pour le commerce des femmes.
Qu'on nous laisse tels que nous sommes. Nos qualités indiscrètes, jointes à nôtre peu de malice, font que les Loix qui gêneroient l'humeur sociable parmi nous, ne seraient point convenables.
French_1748_ch6.translation:
Let us be left as we are," said a gentleman from a nation that closely resembles the one we have just described. Nature fixes everything. She has given us a liveliness capable of offending and apt to make us fail in all respects; this same liveliness is corrected by the politeness she gives us, by inspiring in us a taste for the world and especially for the trade of women.
Let us be as we are. Our indiscreet qualities, combined with our lack of malice, mean that laws that would hinder the sociable mood among us would not be appropriate.

French_1758_ch5.original_text:

French_1758_ch5.translation:

Per questa ragione medesima un' aria pura è alcune volte nociva a coloro, i quali hanno vissuto iu un Paese pantanoso.
Un Veneziano della casata Balbi trovandosi nel Pegù su introdotto alla presenza del Re. Quandò costui seppe, che in Venezia non vi era Re, fece una risata si strabbocchevole, che gli venne una una tosse, che non lo lasciava parlare se non con stento a'suoi Cortigiani. Quale è quel Legislatore, il quale potrebbe proporre un Governo popolare a gente simile?
Italian_1750_ch2.translation:
Nothing seemed more intolerable to the Germans (*They cut out the tongues of the Lawyers, and, vainly says: Viper, let go of whistling. Tacitus.) than the Court of Xaro. That, which on erected by Justinian among the Lazians to try him, who slew their King, seemed to them a horrible, and barbarous thing . Mithridates pleading against the Romans especially reproaches them about the formalities of their justice. The Parthians could not endure that king, who by being educated in Rome had made himself affable, and accessible to all. Liberty itself seemed boring to some of the People, who were not accustomed to enjoy it. For this very reason pure air is sometimes harmful to those who have lived in a marshy country.
A Venetian from the Balbi household finding himself in the Pegu on introduced in the presence of the King. When he heard, that there was no King in Venice, he laughed so heartily, that he had a cough, which did not let him speak except with difficulty to his Courtiers. What is that Legislator, who could propose a popular Government to such people?

Italian_1750_ch3.original_text:
Vi sono due sorte di Tirannia; una reale, la quale consiste nella violenza del Governo ; e l’altra d’opinione, che si fa sentire alloraquando coloro, i quali governano , stabiliscono delle cose, che ripugnano al modo di pensare d’una Nazione.
Dione dice, che Augusto voleva farsi chiamare Romolo; ma che avendo saputo, che il Popolo temeva , ch’ egli volesse farsi Re, mutò disegno . I primi Romani non volevano Re , perchè non ne potevano soffrire la Potenza : i Romani del tempo d’Augusto non volevano Re per non soffrirne le maniere. Imperciocchè quantunque Cesare, i Triumviri, ed Augusto fossero effettivamente Re, avevano conservato tutto l’esteriore dell' uguaglianza, e la loro vita privata conteneva una specie d’ opposizione al fasto de' Re di quei tempi; e quando non volevano Re, ciò significava, che volevano guardare le loro manière, e non prender quelle de’ Popoli d'Africa, e d'Oriente.
Dione ci dice , che il Popolo Romano era sdegnato contra di Augusto per certe Leggi troppo severe, che egli aveva fatte : ma che subitochè egli ebbe fatto ritornare il Commediante Pilade, che le fazzioni avevano cacciato dalla Città, cessarono i disgusti. Un Popolo simile sentiva più vivamente la Tirannia quando si scacciava un Buffone, che quando gli toglievano tutte le sue Leggi.
Italian_1750_ch3.translation:
There are two kinds of Tyranny; one real, which consists in the violence of Government; and the other of opinion, which is felt then when those, who govern, establish things, which are repugnant to the way of thinking of a Nation.
Dion says , that Augustus wanted to be called Romulus ; but that having learned , that the People feared , that he wanted to make himself King , he changed his design . The first Romans did not want to be King , because they could not suffer its Power : the Romans of Augustus' time did not want to be King lest they should suffer its manners . For although Caesar, the Triumvirs, and Augustus were actually kings , they had preserved all the outward equality , and their private life contained a kind of opposition to the pomp of the kings of those times ; and when they did not want kings , it meant , that they wanted to watch their manners , and not take those of the Peoples of Africa , and of the East .
Dione tells us , that the Roman People were indignant against Augustus for certain Laws that were too severe, which he had made : but that as soon as he had brought back the Commedian Pilade, whom the factions had driven out of the City, the disgust ceased. Such a People felt Tyranny more keenly when a Buffoon was driven out, than when all his Laws were taken away.

Italian_1750_ch4.original_text:
Molte sono le cose, che governano gli Uomini ; il Clima, la Religione, le Leggi, le Massime del Governo, gli Esempi delle cose passate, i Costumi, e le Manière; e tutte queste formano un Spirito generale, che n’è l'effetto.
A proporzione, che in ciascuna Nazione agisce con maggior forza una di queste cagioni, le altre cedono tanto maggiormente a questa. La Natura, ed il Clima dominano quasi soli sovra de' Selvaggi; le Maniere governano i Chinesi; le Leggi tirannizzano il Giappone; i Costumi ponevano altre volte in tuono i Lacedemoni; le Massime del Governo, ed i Costumi antichi regolavano la Città di Roma.
Italian_1750_ch4.translation:
Many are the things, which govern Men ; Climate, Religion, Laws, Maxims of Government, Examples of past things, Customs, and Manners; and all these form a general Spirit, which is the effect.
In proportion as in each Nation one of these causes acts with greater force, the others yield all the more to it. Nature, and Climate dominate almost alone over the Savages; Manners govern the Chineses; Laws tyrannize Japan; Customs put the Lacedaemonians in thunder at other times; Maxims of Government, and Ancient Customs governed the City of Rome.

Italian_1750_ch5.original_title: Con quanta attenzione, conviene vegliare a non cangiare lo Spirito generale di una Nazione.
Italian_1750_ch5.translated_title: How carefully, it is appropriate to watch over not to change the general spirit of a nation.
Italian_1750_ch5.original_text:
Se vi fosse nel Mondo una Nazione, che avesse un' umore sociabile, un' apertura di core, un contento nella vita, un gusto, una facilità a comunicare i suoi pensieri; che fosse vivace piacevole, allegra, alcune volte imprudente, spesso indiscreta ; e che con tutto ciò avesse del coraggio, della generosità, della disinvoltura, e un certo punto d’onore; non si doverebbe pensare a ristringere con delle Leggi le sue maniere, per non opprimere le sue virtù . Se in generale il carattere è buono, cosa importa, che vi si trovino alcuni difetti?
Vi si potrebbe tenere a freno le Donne, far delle Leggi per correggere i loro costumi, e moderare il loro lusso; ma chi sa se non vi si perderebbe un certo gusto, che viene ad essere la sorgente delle ricchezze della Nazione, ed una garbatezza, che vi attrae gli stranieri?
Deve il Legislatore seguire il genio della Nazione, quando non è contrario a i principi del Governo, perchè mai facciamo meglio di quel, che facciamo liberamente, ed a seconda del nostro genio naturale.
Se si dà uno spirito di pedanteria ad una Nazione naturalmente allegra, le Stato non vi acquisterà cosa alcuna, nè pel didentro, nè pel difuori . Lasciatela fare seriamente le cose frivole, ed allegramente le serie.
Italian_1750_ch5.translation:
If there were in the World a Nation, which had a 'sociable mood, an openness of heart, a contentedness in life, a taste, a facility in communicating its thoughts; which was lively pleasant, cheerful, sometimes imprudent, often indiscreet ; and which with all this had some courage, some generosity, some ease, and a certain point of honor ; one should not think of restraining by Laws its manners, lest its virtues should be oppressed . If in general the character is good, what does it matter, that some defects be found in it?
One could keep the Women in check there, make Laws to correct their manners, and moderate their luxury; but who knows whether there would not be lost there a certain taste, which comes to be the source of the wealth of the Nation, and a politeness, which attracts foreigners there?
Must the Legislature follow the genius of the Nation, when it is not contrary to the principles of the Government, because we never do better than that, which we do freely, and according to our natural genius.
If you give a spirit of pedantry to a naturally cheerful Nation, the State will not acquire anything from it, either from within or without . Let it seriously do frivolous things, and cheerfully do serious things.

Italian_1750_ch6.original_title: Che non si deve tutto correggere.
Italian_1750_ch6.translated_title: That everything should not be corrected.
Italian_1750_ch6.original_text:
Che ci lascino come stiamo , diceva un Gentiluomo d’una Nazione, che rassomiglia dimolto a quella, di cui abbiamo dato una idea. La natura provvede a tutto . Essa ci ha dato una vivacità capace di offendere, e propria da farci mancare in ogni cosa; questa medesima vivacità è corretta dalla garbatezza, che essa ci procura, dandoci del gusto pel mondo, e sovra tutto per la conversazione delle Donne.
Che ci lascino tali quali siamo. Le nostre qualità indiscrete, unite alla nostra poca malizia, fanno, che le Leggi, che limiterebbero l'umore sociabile fra di noi, non sarebbero affatto convenevoli.
Italian_1750_ch6.translation:
Let them leave us as we are , said a Gentleman of a Nation, which looks very much like that , of which we have given an idea . Nature provides for everything . It has given us a vivacity capable of offending, and proper to be lacking in everything; this same vivacity is corrected by the gentleness, which it procures for us, giving us some taste for the world, and above all for the conversation of Women.
Let them leave us as we are. Our indiscreet qualities, coupled with our little malice, make, that the Laws, which would limit the sociable mood among us, would not be at all agreeable.

Italian_1777_ch1.translated_title: About the subject of this book.
Italian_1777_ch1.original_text: Questa materia è sommamente estesa. In quella folla d’idee, che mi s’offrono alla mente, avrò più attenzione all' ordine delle cose, che alle cose stesse. Forza è ch'io mi volga a destra, ed a sinistra, che io penetri, e che superi ogni ostacolo.
Italian_1777_ch1.translation: This matter is supremely extensive. In that crowd of ideas, which offer themselves to my mind, I will have more attention to the 'order of things, than to the things themselves. Force it is that I turn to the right, and to the left, that I penetrate, and overcome every obstacle.

Italian_1777_ch2.original_title: Quanto è necessario per le Leggi migliori, che gli animi sieno disposti.
Italian_1777_ch2.translated_title: How necessary it is for the best Laws, that minds be disposed.
Italian_1777_ch2.original_text:
Non vi su cosa, che riuscisse più insoffribile (*Troncavano la lingua agli Avvocati, e diceano finiscila, o vipera, di fischiare. Tacito.) a’popoli della Germania, del Tribunale di Vava. Quello, ch’ eresse Giustiniano presso i Laziani per processar: l'uccisore del loro Re, parve a medesimi orribile, e barbara cosa. Declamando Mitridate contra i Romani, soprattutto gli accagiona per le formalità della loro giustizia. I Parti soffrir non poterono quel Re, il quale sendo stato allevato in Roma si rese affabile (e), ed accessibile a chicchessia. E' riuscita intollerabile la stessa libertà a’ popoli, che non erano usi a goderne. Cosi appunto riesce talor nociva un'aria pura a coloro, che vissuti sono fra le paludi.
Un Veneziano della Casa Balbi, trovandosi al Pegù, ebbe udienza da quel Re. Quando questi intese, che in Venezia non vi era Re, gli venne da rider si forte, che preselo la tosse in guisa, ch' ei stentò molto a parlare co' suoi Cortigiani. Qual è quel Legislatore, che potesse proporre a’ popoli di questa satta il governo popolare?
Italian_1777_ch2.translation:
There on't on thing, that succeeded more insufferable (*They cut off the Lawyers' tongues, and said end it, O viper, of whistling. Tacitus.) to the people of Germany, than the Court of Vava. That, which Justinian erected before the Lazians to try: the slayer of their king, seemed to them horrible, and barbarous. Declaiming Mithridates against the Romans, he especially accuses them by the formalities of their justice. The Parthians could not suffer that king, who having been brought up in Rome made himself affable(e), and accessible to anyone. The same freedom proved intolerable to the peoples, who were not used to enjoying it. So precisely succeeds sometimes harmful a pure air to those, who lived among the swamps.
A Venetian of the House Balbi, being at Pegù, had an audience with that King. When he heard, that there was no King in Venice, he laughed so loudly, that he caught a cough in such a way, that he struggled much to speak with his courtiers. Who is that Legislator, who could propose to the people of this satta the popular government?

Italian_1777_ch3.original_text:
Vi sono due sorte di tirannia, und reale, che consiste nella violenza del Governo, ed una di opinione, che si sa sentire, quando quei, che governano, stabiliscono cose, le quali ripugnano al modo di pensare d’una Nazione.
Dice Dione, che Augusto volle farsi chiamar Romolo; ma che avendo inteso, che il popolo temea, ch'ei volesse farsi Re, mutò pensiero. I primi Romani non voleano Re, perchè non poteano comportarne la potenza; i Romani d’allora non voleano Re, per non comportarne le maniere. Imperciocchè, quantunque Cesare, i Triumviri, Augusto, fossero veri Re, conservavano tutto l’estrinseco dell' uguaglianza: e la loro vita privata conteneva una specie di contrapposto col fasto de Re di quel tempo: e quando non voleano Re, significava, che volean conservare le loro maniere, e non prender quelle dé popoli Africani, e d'Oriente.
Dione ci dice, che il popolo Romano era sdegnato contra di Augusto a motivo di certe leggi troppo dure, che avea fatte; ma che subito ch'egli ebbe fatto ritornare il Commediante Pilade, che le fazioni aveano discacciato dalla Citrà, il disgusto cessò. Un popolo simile sentiva più vivamente la tirannia, allorchè si discacciava un buffone, che quando gli toglieano tutte le sue Leggi.
Italian_1777_ch3.translation:
There are two kinds of tyranny, und real, which consists in the violence of government, and one of opinion, which is known to be felt, when those, who govern, establish things, which are repugnant to the way of thinking of a Nation.
Dione says, that Augustus wanted to be called Romulus; but that having heard, that the people feared, that he wanted to make himself King, he changed his mind. The early Romans did not want to be king, because they could not comport with his power; the Romans of that time did not want to be king, lest they should comport with his manners. For although Caesar, the Triumvirs, Augustus, were true kings, they retained all the extrinsic of 'equality: and their private life contained a kind of contrast with the pomp of the kings of that time: and when they did not want kings, it meant, that they wished to preserve their manners, and not to take those of the African peoples, and of the East.
Dione tells us, that the Roman people were indignant against Augustus on account of certain too harsh laws, which he had made; but that as soon as he had brought back the Commedian Pilades, whom the factions had driven from the City, the disgust ceased. Such a people felt tyranny more keenly, when a jester was cast out, than when they took away all their Laws.

Italian_1777_ch4.original_text:
Plu cose governano gli nomini, il clima, la Religione, le Leggi, le massime del governo, gli esempi delle cose passate, i costumi, le maniere, dal che viene a formarsi uno spirito generale, che ne risulta.
A misura, che in ciascuna Nazione una di queste cagioni agisce con più vigore, le altre le cedono. La natura, ed il elima dominano quasi soli sopra i Selvaggi: le maniere governano i Chinesi: le leggi tiranneggiano il Giappone: i costumi signoreggiavano un tempo in Isparta, le massime del governo, ed i costumi antichi in Roma.
Italian_1777_ch4.translation:
Plu things govern appointments, climate, Religion, Laws, maxims of government, examples of past things, customs, manners, from which a general spirit is formed, which results.
To the extent, that in each nation one of these causes acts more vigorously, the others yield to it. Nature, and elima rule almost alone over the Savages: manners rule the Chinese: laws tyrannize Japan: customs once ruled in Isparta, the maxims of government, and ancient customs in Rome.

Italian_1777_ch5.original_title: Quanto convenga avvertire di non mutare lo Spirito generale d'una Nazione.
Italian_1777_ch5.translated_title: How appropriate to warn not to change the general Spirit of a Nation.
Italian_1777_ch5.original_text:
Se nol mondo esistesse una Nazione, la quale avesse un umor socievole, un' espansione di cuore, un contento nella vita, un gusto, una facilità a comunicare i propri pensamenti: che fosse vivace, piacevole, gaja, talora imprudente, con frequenza indiscreta: e che con tutto questo fosse coraggiosa, generosa, franca, e che avesse un certo punto d’onore, non converrebbe studiarsi di ristringere con leggi le sue maniere, per non ristringere le sue virtù. Se generalmente il carattere è buono, che rileva, che vi si trovino alcuni difetti?
Vi si potrebbero tener a segno le femmine, far leggi per correggere i loro costumi, e por termine al loro lusso: ma chi sa, non vi si perdesse un certo gusto, che fosse la sorgente delle ricchezze della Nazione, ed una gentilezza, che chiama a se i forestieri?
Sta al Legislatore il seguir lo spirito della nazione, allorchè non si oppone a’ principj del governo; poichè noa facciamo mai meglio alcuna cosa, che quando la facciamo liberamente, ed a seconda del nostro genio naturale.
Che diasi ad una nazione gaja per natura uno spirito pedantesco, nulla vi guadagnerà lo Stato nè al di dentro, nè al di fuori. Lasciatelo fare le cose frivole con serietà, e le serie con brio.
Italian_1777_ch5.translation:
If nol world existed a Nation, which had a sociable humor, an 'expansion of heart, a contentment in life, a taste, a facility in communicating its thoughts: that it was lively, pleasant, gaja, sometimes imprudent, with indiscreet frequency: and that with all this it was brave, generous, frank, and had a certain point of honor, would it not be convenient to study to curtail by laws its manners, so as not to curtail its virtues. If generally the character is good, what detects, that some faults be found in it?
One could keep females in check there, make laws to correct their manners, and put an end to their luxury: but who knows, would not there be lost a certain taste, which was the source of the wealth of the nation, and a kindness, which calls to strangers?
It is for the Legislature to follow the spirit of the nation, when it does not oppose the principles of government; for noa do we ever do any thing better, than when we do it freely, and according to our natural genius.
That you give to a gaja nation by nature a pedantic spirit, nothing will gain you the state either within or without. Let it do frivolous things with seriousness, and serious things with brio.

Italian_1777_ch6.original_title: Non esser necessario il corregger tutto.
Italian_1777_ch6.translated_title: Don't be necessary to correct everything.
Italian_1777_ch6.original_text:
Ci si lasci come ci troviamo, diceva un Gentiluomo d’una Nazione molto analoga a quella, di cui abbiamo data un' idea. Tutto ripara la natura. Ci ha essa data una vivacità capace d'offendere, ed atta a farci mancare a tutt'i riguardi: questa stessa vivacità vien corretta dalla gentilezza, che ci proccura, inspirandoci del gusto pel mondo, e singolarmente per la conversazione delle donne.
Ci si lasci tali quali siamo. Le nostre indiscrete qualità unite alla scarsa nostra malizia, fanno, che le leggi, le quali limitassero l'umore sociabile fra noi, non ci converrebbero.
Italian_1777_ch6.translation:
Let us be left as we are, said a Gentleman of a Nation very similar to that, of which we have given an 'idea. Everything repairs nature. It has given us a liveliness capable of offending, and apt to make us lack all respect: this same liveliness is corrected by kindness, which proccures us, inspiring us with a taste for the world, and singularly for the conversation of women.
Let us be left as we are. Our indiscreet qualities united with our little malice, make, that laws, which would limit the sociable mood among us, would not suit us.

German_1753_ch1.translated_title: From the contents of this book.
German_1753_ch1.original_text: Diese Materie ist sehr weitläuftig. Ben einer so großen Menge von Begriffen, die mir vorkommen, werde ich mehr auf die Ordnung der Sachen, als auf die Sachen selbst sehen. Ich muß mich bald zur Rechten, bald zur Linken wenden, und mir eine Oeffnung machen, damit ich freye Aussicht gewinne.
German_1753_ch1.translation: This matter is very broad. With such a large number of concepts before me, I will look more at the order of things than at the things themselves. I must turn sometimes to the right, sometimes to the left, and make an opening for myself in order to gain a clear view.

German_1753_ch2.original_title: Wie nothwendig es auch für die besten Gesetze ist, daß die Gemüther etwa vorbereitet sind.
German_1753_ch2.translated_title: How necessary it is, even for the best laws, that the minds should be prepared.
German_1753_ch2.original_text:
Nichts schien den Deutschen unerträglicher, (*Sie schnitten den Sachwaltern die Zungen ab, und sprachen: Otter höre auf zu zischen. Tacitus.) als das Gericht des Varus. Dasjenige, welches Justinian bey den Laziern anordnete, um dem Königsmörder den Proceß zu machen, schien ihnen erschrecklich und grausam. Als Mithridates wider die Römer eine Rede hielte, so verwieß er ihnen insbesondere die Formalitäten ihrer Gerichtsbarkeit. Die Parther konnten den König nicht leiden, der, weil er in Rom erzogen worden, sich beliebt zu machen wuste, und jedermann vor sich ließ. Selbst die Freyheit hat Leuten unerträglich geschienen, denen der Genuß derselben etwas ungewohntes war. Ohngefehr wie eine reine Luft denenjenigen bisweilen schadet, die in morastigen Ländern gelebet haben.
Ein Venetianer, Namens Balbi, kam nach Pegu und wurde vor den König gelassen. Wie dieser dieser vernahm, daß Venedig keinen König hätte, lachte er dermaßen laut, daß ihn ein Husten überfiel, und er kaum im Stande war, zu seinen Hofleuten zu reden. Was würde wohl das für ein Gesetzgeber seyn, der solchen Völkern eine Regierung gäbe, die das Volk in Händen hätte?
German_1753_ch2.translation:
Nothing seemed more unbearable to the Germans (*They cut off the tongues of the stewards and said: Otter stop hissing. Tacitus.) than the judgment of Varus. The one that Justinian ordered the Lazians to try the regicide seemed frightening and cruel to them. When Mithridates made a speech against the Romans, he particularly rebuked the formalities of their jurisdiction. The Parthians could not stand the king who, because he had been educated in Rome, knew how to make himself popular and let everyone go before him. Even freedom seemed unbearable to people who were unaccustomed to enjoying it. No more so than pure air sometimes harms those who have lived in swampy countries.
A Venetian named Balbi came to Pegu and was brought before the king. When he heard that Venice had no king, he laughed so loudly that he was seized with a cough, and was hardly able to speak to his courtiers. What sort of a legislator would he be, who would give such nations a government which the people had in their hands?

German_1753_ch3.original_text:
Man hat zwo Arten der Tyranney; eine wirkliche, die in einer gewaltsamen Regierung bestehet; die und eine welche mit in der Einbildung bestehet, man alsdenn fühlet, wenn von denen, die das Regiement führen, Dinge festgestellt werden, so die Denkungsart einer Nation beleidigen.
Dio berichtet, Augustus habe sich wollen Romulus nennen lassen; jedoch unterließ er sein Vorhaben, da er hörte, daß das Volk besorgt war, er möchte sich zum Könige machen. Die ersten Römer verlangten keine Könige, weil sie ihre Gewalt nicht leiden könnten. Die damaligen Römer hergegen verlangten deswegen keinen König, weil ihnen die Sitten eines Königes zuwider waren. Denn ob schon Cäsar, die Triumviri und Augustus wirkliche Könige gewesen, so suchten sie doch äusserlich mit jedermann, als mit ihres gleichen umzugehen. Ihr Privatleben war dem Prachte der damaligen Könige entgegen gesetzt, und wenn sie keinen König wünschten, so war solches eine Anzeige, daß sie ihre Lebensart behalten, nicht aber die afrikanische oder morgenländische annehmen wolten.
Dio meldet ferner, (g) daß das römische Volk gegen den August aufgebracht worden, weil er ihnen einige zu harte Gesetze gegeben hatte; doch so bald er den Comödianten Pylades, den die Unruhigen aus der Stadt gejaget hatten, zurück berufen, so habe sich der Unwillen des Volks geleget. Ein solches Volk fühlte die Tyranney weit lebhafter, wenn man einen Comödientänzer wegjagte, als wenn man ihm alle seine Gesetze nahm.
German_1753_ch3.translation:
There are two kinds of tyranny; one real, which consists in violent government; the other imaginary, which is felt when those who govern establish things that offend the mind of a nation.
Dio reports that Augustus wanted to be called Romulus; however, he refrained from doing so because he heard that the people were worried that he would make himself king. The first Romans did not demand kings because they could not stand their power. The Romans of that time, on the other hand, did not demand a king because they disliked the customs of a king. For although Caesar, the Triumviri and Augustus were real kings, outwardly they sought to treat everyone as their equal. Their private life was opposed to the splendor of the kings of that time, and if they did not want a king, it was an indication that they wanted to keep their way of life, but not adopt the African or Oriental way.
Dio further reports (g) that the Roman people had become enraged against Augustus because he had given them some laws that were too harsh; but as soon as he recalled the comedian Pylades, whom the unruly had chased out of the city, the people's displeasure had subsided. Such a people felt the tyranny far more vividly when a comedian was chased away than when all their laws were taken away.

German_1753_ch4.translated_title: In which the general spirit consists.
German_1753_ch4.original_text:
Die Menschen lassen sich durch vielerley Dinge regieren, durchs Clima, durch die Religion und Gesetze, durch die Staatsgriffe in der Regierung, durch die Beyspiele der vergangenen Dinge, durch die Sitten und Lebensarten. Hieraus entstehet nun ein allgemeiner Geist, eine allgemeine Gemüthsbeschaffenheit und Gesinnung.
Je heftiger eine von diesen Ursachen in einem Lande wirket, desto geringer wirken die andern. Die Natur und das Clima haben fast allein über die Wilden eine Gewalt. Die Chineser lassen sich durch die Lebensart regieren. Die Gesetze herrschen tyrannisch über die Japonier. In Lacedämon richtete man sich ehedem nach den Sitten, und in Rom nach den Kunstgriffen der Regierung und den alten Gebräuchen.
German_1753_ch4.translation:
Men allow themselves to be governed by many things, by the climate, by religion and laws, by state action in government, by the examples of things past, by customs and ways of life. From this arises a general spirit, a general state of mind and disposition.
The more strongly one of these causes acts in a country, the less strongly the others act. Nature and the climate have almost sole power over the savages. The Chinese allow themselves to be ruled by their way of life. The laws rule tyrannically over the Japonians. In Lacedæmon they were formerly governed by custom, and in Rome by the artifices of government and ancient usages.

German_1753_ch5.original_title: Wie sehr man darauf Acht zu geben hat, daß der allgemeine Geist der Nation nicht verändert werde.
German_1753_ch5.translated_title: How much care must be taken to ensure that the general spirit of the nation is not changed.
German_1753_ch5.original_text:
Fände sich eine Nation in der Welt, die eine gesellige Gemüthsart, eine Offenherzigkeit, ein Vergnügen im Leben, einen Geschmack und eine Leichtigkeit ihre Gedanken andern mitzutheilen besäße; wenn sie ferner lebhaft, angenehm, lustig, zuweilen etwas einfältig, öfters auch etwas unbedachtsam wäre: ja wenn sie bey dem allen dennoch tapfer, edelmüthig, redlich wäre, und auf Ehre hielte, so dürfte man ihre Lebensart durch keine Gesetze einschränken, um nicht zugleich ihre Tugenden einzuschränken. Ist die Gemüthsart überhaupt gut, so schadet es nichts, wenn sich einige Fehler darinnen finden.
Man würde daselbst das Frauenzimmer im Zügel halten, und Gesetze geben können, die ihre Sitten besserten und ihren Uebermuth einschränkten; wer weiß aber, ob man nicht dadurch einen gewissen Geschmack abschaffen würde, der die Quelle des Reichthums der Nation wäre, und eine gewisse Artigkeit, die die Ausländer anlocket, vertrieben würde. Dem Gesetzgeber liegt ob, sich nach der Neigung der Nation zu richten, wenn sie anders den Grundsätzen der Regierung nicht zuwider ist. Denn es geht uns doch nichts besser von statten, als was wir frey und nach unserer Gemüthsneigung unternehmen.
Man gebe einer von Natur lustigen Nation eine gewisse pedantische Neigung, der Staat wird nichts dabey weder von innen noch von aussen gewinnen. Man lasse ihr die unnützen Dinge ernsthaft, die ernsthaften aber lustig ausrichten.
German_1753_ch5.translation:
If there were a nation in the world which possessed a sociable disposition, an open-heartedness, a pleasure in life, a taste and an ease in communicating its thoughts to others; if it were also lively, pleasant, merry, sometimes a little simple-minded, often also a little careless: indeed, if in all this it were nevertheless brave, noble-minded, honest, and held to honor, its way of life should not be restricted by any laws in order not to restrict its virtues at the same time. If the disposition is generally good, it does no harm if some faults are to be found in it.
It would be possible there to keep women in check, and to pass laws which would improve their manners and restrain their wantonness; but who knows whether this would not abolish a certain taste which is the source of the nation's wealth, and drive away a certain nobility which attracts foreigners. It is for the legislator to act according to the inclination of the nation, if it is not otherwise contrary to the principles of the government. For nothing is better for us than what we undertake freely and according to our inclination.
Give a nation, which is by nature merry, a certain pedantic disposition, and the state will gain nothing by it, either from within or from without. Let it do the useless things seriously, but the serious things amusingly.

German_1753_ch6.translated_title: You don't have to improve everything.
German_1753_ch6.original_text:
Man lasse uns wie wir sind, sprach ein Edelmann aus einer gewissen Nation, die derjenigen ziemlich gleich kömmt, von der wir einen Begriff gegeben haben. Die Natur bringt alles zurechte. Sie hat uns mit einer gewissen Lebhaftigkeit begabet, damit wir bisweilen andere beleidigen und alle Hochachtung gegen sie aus den Augen setzen. Jedoch wird eben diese Lebhaftigkeit durch die Höflichkeit verbessert, die uns die Natur an die Hand giebt, indem sie uns den Umgang und insbesondere das Frauenzimmer angenehm machet.
Man lasse uns nur immer so, wie wir sind. Unsere unbescheidenen Eigenschaften, die mit etwas Leichtfertigkeit verbunden sind, verursachen, daß Gesetze, die eine gesellige Gemüthsart zwingen würden, keinesweges zuträglich seyn möchten.
German_1753_ch6.translation:
Let us be as we are, said a nobleman from a certain nation, which is quite similar to the one we have described. Nature makes everything right. It has endowed us with a certain vivacity, so that we sometimes offend others and lose all respect for them. However, this liveliness is improved by the politeness that nature gives us by making our company, and especially women, pleasant.
We should always be left as we are. Our immodest qualities, which are connected with a certain frivolity, cause that laws which would compel a sociable disposition are by no means conducive to it.

German_1799_ch1.translated_title: From the contents of this book.
German_1799_ch1.original_text: Diese Materie geht sehr ins Weite. Bey der Menge von Ideen, die meinem Verstande sich darstellen, werde ich aufmerksamer auf die Ordnung der Sachen, als auf die Sachen selbst seyn. Ich muß zur Rechten und zur Linken abwehren, muß mich durcharbeiten und mir Licht schaffen.
German_1799_ch1.translation: This matter is very broad. With the multitude of ideas that present themselves to my mind, I will be more attentive to the order of things than to the things themselves. I must ward off to the right and to the left, must work my way through and create light for myself.

German_1799_ch2.original_title: Wie nothwendig es für die besten Gesetze ist, daß die Gemülher vorbereitet seyen.
German_1799_ch2.translated_title: How necessary it is for the best laws that the minds be prepared.
German_1799_ch2.original_text:
Nichts kam den Deutschen unerträglicher vor, als das Tribunal des Varus. (*Sie schnitten den Sachwaltern die Zunge aus, und sprachen: Otter, hör auf zu zischen. Tacitus.) Das Gericht, welches Justinian bey den Laziern anordnete, um dem Mörder ihres Königs den Prozeß zu machen, war in ihren Augen etwas Entsetzliches und Barbarisches. Mithridat, wenn er in der Anrede an sein Heer wider die Römer eifert, wirft ihnen häuptsächlich ihre rechtlichen Formalitäten vor. Die Parther konnten jenen König nicht ausstehen, der, da er in Rom erzogen worden, leutselig war, und jedermann den Zutritt verstattete. Die Freyheit selbst ist Völkern unerträglich vorgekommen, die nicht gewohnt waren, derselben zu genießen. So ist bisweilen eine reine Luft denjenigen schädlich, die in morastigen Ländern gelebt haben.
Ein Venetianer, mit Nahmen Balbi, erhielt bey seinem Aufenthalte in Pegu bey dem dasigen Könige Audienz. Als dieser hörte, in Venedig wäre kein König, brach er in ein so großes Gelächter aus, daß er darüber ins Husten kam, und viele Mühe hatte, zu seinen Hofleuten zu reden. Wer ist der Gesetzgeber, der Völkern von der Art die Volksregierung vorschlagen könnte?
German_1799_ch2.translation:
Nothing seemed more unbearable to the Germans than the tribunal of Varus. (*They cut out the tongues of the stewards and said: Otter, stop hissing. Tacitus.) The court which Justinian ordered the Lazians to hold for the murderer of their king was something horrible and barbaric in their eyes. Mithridat, when he is jealous of the Romans in his address to his army, mainly reproaches them for their legal formalities. The Parthians could not stand the king who, having been educated in Rome, was affable and allowed anyone to enter. Freedom itself has seemed unbearable to peoples who were not used to enjoying it. Thus, clean air is sometimes harmful to those who have lived in swampy countries.
A Venetian by the name of Balbi was given audience with the king during his stay in Pegu. When he heard that there was no king in Venice, he burst out laughing so loudly that he began to cough and had great difficulty speaking to his courtiers. Who is the legislator who could propose popular government to peoples of this kind?

German_1799_ch3.original_text:
Es gibt zwey Arten von Tyranney: eine wirkliche, welche in der Gewaltthätigkeit der Regierung bestehet, und eine auf Meinung beruhende Tyranney. Diese äußert sich, wenn diejenigen, welche am Ruder sitzen, Dinge veststellen, die der Denkungsart einer Nation anstößig sind.
Dio sagt, August habe sich wollen Romulus nennen lassen, habe aber, als er gehört, das Volk fürchte, er wolle sich zum Könige machen, dieß Vorhaben aufgegeben. Die ersten Römer wollten von keinem Könige wissen, weil sie die Macht eines Königs nicht ausstehen konnten; die damahligen Römer wollten von keinem Könige wissen, um das äußere Betragen eines Königs nicht dulden zu dürfen. Denn obgleich Cäsar, die Triumvire, August, wirkliche Könige waren, so hatten sie doch in ihrem Umgange mit jedermann sich völlig so betragen, als wenn sie seines Gleichen wären, und ihr Privat-Leben machte eine Art von Gegensatz in Beziehung auf die stolze Pracht der damahligen Könige aus; und wenn die Römer von keinem Könige wissen wollten, so hieß das so viel, sie wollten ihre bisherigen Sitten und Lebensart beybehalten, und nicht der afrikanischen und orientalischen Völker ihre annehmen.
Dio berichtet, das römische Volk sey wider Augusten, gewisser zu harten Gesetze wegen, die er gegeben hatte; aufgebracht gewesen; so bald er aber den Komödianten Pylades habe zurückkommen lassen, den die Factionen aus der Stadt vertrieben hatten, habe das Mißvergnügen aufgehöret. Ein solches Volk fühlt die Tyranney lebhafter, wenn man einen Possenreisser fortjagte, als wenn man ihm alle seine Gesetze entzog.
German_1799_ch3.translation:
There are two types of tyranny: real tyranny, which consists in the government's use of force, and tyranny based on opinion. The latter manifests itself when those at the helm say things that are offensive to a nation's way of thinking.
Dio says that Augustus wanted to be called Romulus, but when he heard that the people feared that he wanted to make himself king, he gave up this plan. The early Romans did not want to know of any kings because they could not stand the power of a king; the Romans of that time did not want to know of any kings because they could not tolerate the outward behavior of a king. For although Caesar, the Triumvirs, Augustus, were real kings, yet in their intercourse with every one they had behaved entirely as if they were his equals, and their private life made a kind of contrast with the proud splendor of the kings of that time; and if the Romans did not wish to know of any kings, it meant that they wished to retain their former manners and mode of life, and not to adopt theirs from the African and Oriental peoples.
Dio reports that the Roman people were angry with Augustus because of certain excessively harsh laws he had made, but that as soon as he had allowed the comedian Pylades to return, whom the factions had expelled from the city, the displeasure had ceased. Such a people feel the tyranny more keenly when a buffoon is chased away than when all their laws are taken away.

German_1799_ch4.translated_title: What the general spirit consists of.
German_1799_ch4.original_text: Mehrere Dinge regieren die Menschen: das Clima, die Religion, die Gesetze, die Maximen der Regierung, die Beyspiele der vergangenen Dinge, die Sitten, die Lebensarten. Hierdurch wird ein allgemeiner Geist, das Resultat hiervon, gebildet. Je stärker bey jeder Nation eine dieser Ursachen wirkt, je schwächer wirken die übrigen. Die Natur und das Clima herrschen fast allein über die Wilden; durch die Lebensart, durch die Manieren werden die Sineser regieret; die Gesetze tyrannisiren Japon; die Sitten gaben ehedem den Ton in Lacedämon: die Marimen der Regierung und die alten Sitten gaben ihn in Rom.
German_1799_ch4.translation: Several things govern men: the climate, religion, laws, maxims of government, examples of past things, customs, ways of life. A general spirit is formed as a result of these. The more strongly one of these causes acts in each nation, the more weakly the others act. Nature and the climate rule almost alone over the savages; the Sines are governed by the way of life, by manners; the laws tyrannize over Japon; the customs formerly set the tone in Lacedemon: the marimes of government and the old customs set it in Rome.

German_1799_ch5.original_title: Wie sehr man darauf sehen muß, den allgemeinen Geist einer Nation nicht umzuändern.
German_1799_ch5.translated_title: How careful one must be not to change the general spirit of a nation.
German_1799_ch5.original_text:
Gäbe es in der Welt eine Nation, die eine gefällige Gemüthsart, eine gewisse Offenherzigkeit, Fröhlichkeit im Umgange, Leichtheit, ihre Gedanken mittzutheilen, besäße; die lebhaft, gefallend, aufgeräumt, bisweilen unweise, oft unbedachtsam wäre; und der dabey Herzhaftigkeit, Edelmuth, Freymüthigkeit, ein gewisses Point d'honneur eigen wäre: so müßte man nicht suchen, durch Gesetze ihrer Lebensart, ihren Manieren Zwang anzuthun, um ihre Tugenden keinem Zwange zu unterwerfen. Ist überhaupt genommen der Charakter gut, was haben einige ihm anklebende Fehler zu bedeuten?
Man könnte bey einer solchen Nation die Frauenzimmer einschränken, könnte auf die Verbesserung ihrer Sitten und die Zügelung ihrer üppigkeit abzweckende Gesetze geben; wer weiß aber, ob man alsdann nicht einen gewissen Geschmack, der die Quelle der Reichthümer der Nation wäre, und eine gewisse Artigkeit, die die Ausländer herbey lockt, verscheuchen würde?
Dem Gesetzgeber liegt ob, sich nach dem Geiste der Nation zu bequemen, wenn derselbe nicht wider die Grundsätze der Regierung streitet; denn nichts verrichten wir besser, als was wir ohne Zwang und unserm natürlichen Charakter zu Folge verrichten.
Man gebe einer von Natur frohen und muntern Nation einen Pedanterey-Geist, eine pedantische Richtung, der Staat wird dabey nichts, weder für sein inneres, noch für sein äußeres Interesse gewinnen. Laß sie immerhin die nichtswürdigen Dinge ernsthaft, und die ernsthaften lustig betreiben.
German_1799_ch5.translation:
If there were a nation in the world which possessed a pleasing disposition, a certain frankness, cheerfulness of manner, ease in communicating its thoughts; which was lively, pleasing, uncluttered, sometimes unwise, often careless; and which at the same time possessed cordiality, nobleness, liberality, a certain point d'honneur: it would not be necessary to seek to impose laws on her manner of life, her manners, in order not to subject her virtues to compulsion. If character is good in the first place, what is the meaning of a few faults clinging to it?
One could restrict the women of such a nation, could make laws aimed at improving their manners and restraining their opulence; but who knows whether this would not scare away a certain taste, which would be the source of the nation's wealth, and a certain nobility that attracts foreigners?
It behooves the legislator to conform to the spirit of the nation, if it does not conflict with the principles of government; for we do nothing better than what we do without compulsion and in accordance with our natural character.
Give a naturally happy and cheerful nation a pedantic spirit, a pedantic direction, and the state will gain nothing, neither for its internal nor for its external interests. At least let them do the unworthy things seriously, and the serious things amusingly.

German_1799_ch6.translated_title: You don't have to improve everything.
German_1799_ch6.original_text:
Man lasse uns, wie wir sind, sprach ein Edelmann aus einer Nation, die der jetzt eben beschriebenen sehr gleich sieht. Die Natur bringt alles zurechte. Sie hat uns eine Lebhaftigkeit verliehen, die beleidigend werden und uns verleiten könnte, alle Achtung gegen andre zu vergessen; eben diese Lebhaftigkeit wird gemildert durch die Höflichkeit, welche sie uns eigen macht, indem sie uns Geschmack am Umgange, und vorzüglich am Umgange mit Frauenzimmer, einflößet.
Man lasse uns, wie wir sind. Unser Leichtsinn und Unbedachtsamkeit, mit unserm Bißchen Bösartigkeit verbunden, verursachen, daß die Gesetze, welche der Neigung zur Geselligkeit unter uns Zwang anthun würden, nicht zuträglich seyn dürften.
German_1799_ch6.translation:
Leave us as we are, said a nobleman from a nation that looks very much like the one just described. Nature makes everything right. It has given us a vivacity which could become offensive and tempt us to forget all respect for others; this very vivacity is tempered by the politeness which it makes our own by instilling in us a taste for intercourse, and especially for intercourse with women.
Let us be as we are. Our frivolity and carelessness, combined with our little bit of malice, cause that the laws which would force the inclination to sociability among us should not be conducive.

Polish_1777_ch1.original_text: Wa materyia bardzo obszerna. W tym nacisku myśli, które mi na umyśle stawaią, pilnieysze oko na porządek, niż na same rzeczy mieć będę. Muszę w prawą y na lewą odsuwać, przebiiać, y pole sobie otworzyć.
Polish_1777_ch1.translation: Wa materyia very extensive. In this pressure of thoughts that stawai me on my mind, I will have a keener eye for order than for the things themselves. I have to push to the right y to the left, pierce, y field open to myself.

Polish_1777_ch2.original_title: Jako naylepszym Prawom potrzebna, żeby duchy przygotowane zostały.
Polish_1777_ch2.translated_title: As nay better Laws needed, so that the spirits are prepared.
Polish_1777_ch2.original_text:
Nic tak nieznośnego niezdało się Niemcom iako Wara Trybunał. Inszy, ktory Justynian założył u Lazyow żeby sądził Zaboycę ich Krola, zdał się im rzeczą straszliwą y Barbarzyńską. Mitrydates maiąc mowę przeciw Rzymianom, wyrzuca im na oczy szczegulnie tryby sądowe.
Niemogli Partowie znieść Krola tego co bywszy wychowany w Rzymie stał się łagodnym y przystępnym dla wszytkich. Wolność sama zdała się ludziom nieznośna, co zażywać niezwyczayni iey byli. Tak to nawet czasem czyste powietrze zabiia tych co w bagnistych wychowani Krainach.
Weneczyk nazwiskiem Balbi znayduiąc się w Pegu był wprowadzony do Krola; ktory gdy się dowiedział że nie ma Krola Wenecya, tak się począł śmiać do rozpuku, że się tak mocno zaksztusił, iż ciężko mu było do Dworskich swoich przemowić. Ktoryż by Prawodawca potrasił wprowadzić u takich ludzi rząd gminny?
Polish_1777_ch2.translation:
Nothing was so unbearable for the Germans as the Wara Tribunal. Another tribunal, which Justinian set up at Lazyow to judge their King Zaboyca, seemed to them a terrible and barbaric thing. Mithridates, having a speech against the Romans, throws out to them especially the tribunals.
The Parthians couldn't stand the king who, having been raised in Rome, became gentle and approachable to all. Freedom itself seemed unbearable to the people, who were not used to it. So even the clean air sometimes kills those who grew up in swampy lands.
A Venerable by the name of Balbi, who was in Pegu, was introduced to the King, who, when he found out that there was no King of Venice, began to laugh so hard that he choked so much that it was difficult for him to speak to his courtiers. Who would be able to introduce a municipal government to such people?

Polish_1777_ch3.original_text:
Dwa są Tyrannij gatunki, iedna rzetelna, która od gwałtu rządu zawisła; a druga rozumienia, która czuć się daie gdy rządzący rzeczy stanowią ktore obrażaią sposób Kraiu myślenia.
Mowi Dion: że August chciaf się nazwać Romulem; lecz uwiadomiony iż lud został ztrwożony, ażeby się Krolem niezrobił, odmienił zamysł. Niechcieli Krola pierwsi Rzymianie, bo niemogli iego znieść mocy. Poźnieysi Rzymianie Krola niechcieli, żeby maniery iego niecierpieć. Bo chociaż Cesar, Trzey mężowic, August, byli Krole prawdziwi, iednak powierzchownie przestrzegali cale rowności, a życie ich prywatne miało nieiaką sprzeciwność okazałości Krolewskiey; a czasów owych kiedy Krola niechcieli, to znaczyło że chcieli maniery własne zachować, anie przeymować Afrykańskie, ani wschodnich Narodow.
Mowi ieszcze Dion: że na Augusta rozdąfał się lud Rzymski za prawa niektore zbyt ostre, ale že skoro tylko kazaf nazad powrocić Komedyantowi Piladzie fakcyami wygnanemu z Miasta, zaraz złe chęci zgasły. Lud taki żywiey czuł Tyranią, gdy Tanecznika wygnano, niż gdy go wyzuwali z praw wszytkich.
Polish_1777_ch3.translation:
There are two species of Tyrannical, one of integrity, which hangs on the violence of government; and the other of understanding, which can be felt when those in power make things that offend the country's way of thinking.
Dion says that Augustus wanted to call himself Romulus, but realizing that the people had been persuaded not to make him King, he changed his mind. The first Romans did not want a king, because they could not stand his power. The later Romans did not want the King, because they could not bear his manners. For although the Emperor, the Three Men, and Augustus were kings in truth, yet they superficially observed equality, and their private lives were in little opposition to the splendor of kingship; and in those days when they disliked the king, it meant that they wished to preserve their own manners, and not to overthink those of the Africans or of the eastern nations.
Dion says that the people of Rome were angry with Augustus for some laws that were too harsh, but that as soon as he ordered the return of the Comedian Pilada, who had been banished from the City, the ill will immediately died down. Such a people felt Tyranny more vividly when the Comedian was banished than when they were expelled from all rights.

Polish_1777_ch4.original_text:
Wiele rzeczy ludźmi kieruie, Natura Kraiu, Religia, Prawa, Maxymy rządowe, przykłady przeszłych rzeczy, Obyczaie, Maniery, a z tego pokleiony duch ogulny wynika.
Im bardziey każdy Narod która ta przyczyna znacznieyszą siłą porusza, insze ustępuią tym lepiey. Sama prawie natura y położenie Kraiu nad dzikiemi panuią; maniery rządzą Chinami; Prawa uciskaią Japonow; niegdy w Lacedemonie obyczaie miały Starszeństwo. Maxymy rządowe y Obyczaie Starożytne w Rzymie znaydowały moc pierwsżą.
Polish_1777_ch4.translation:
Many things guide people, the Nature of the Country, Religion, Laws, Governmental Maxims, examples of past things, Customs, Manners, and from this the general spirit arises.
The more each Nation which this cause moves by a much greater force, the other give way the better. The very nature and location of the country overpowers the wild ones; manners rule China; laws oppress the Japanese; once in Lacedemon customs had the upper hand. The governmental maxims and customs of Antiquity in Rome have known the power of the first.

Polish_1777_ch5.original_title: Jak wielkiey trzeba pilności żeby nieodmienić ogulnego ducha w Narodzie.
Polish_1777_ch5.translated_title: How greaty trzeba diligence to not change the ogular spirit in the Nation.
Polish_1777_ch5.original_text:
Gdyby gdzie był Narod towarzyskiego humoru, szczerości serca znaczney, wesosy w życiu, z smakiem y snadnością w udzielaniu swych myśli, a byłby żywy, przyiemny iemny, wdzięczny, czasem nierostropny, często natrętny; y gdyby przytym miał męstwo, wspaniałość, rzetelność, pewny punkt honoru, nienależałoby ściskać manier iego prawami, ażeby cnoty iego nieztłumić. Gdy charakter dobry ogulnie, coż natym że niektore ma wady?
Kobiety możnaby wstrzymać stanowiąc prawa do poprawy ich obyczaiow, y określaiąc zbytek: lecz ktoż wie ieśliby nie zginął smak pewny, który byłby źrzodłem bogactw Narodu, y ta grzeczność, co Cudzoziemców powabem?
Do Prawodawcy to należy trzymać się ducha Narodu, gdy rządu nieprzeciwny istocie, bo nigdy nieczyniemy lepiey, iak co wolnie y zgodnie z przyrodzonym duchem czyniemy.
Niech w Narodzie z przyrodzenia wesołym mędrkowania ducha zaszczepią, nic na tym Państwo wewnątrz, ani zewnątrz niezyska. Pozwolcie mu lekkie rzeczy czynić poważnie, a poważne wesofo.
Polish_1777_ch5.translation:
If there was a nation of sociable humor, sincere heart, cheerful in life, with a taste for and a sense of humor in the expression of his thoughts, and he was lively, earthy, graceful, sometimes rough, often obtrusive; and if at the same time he had courage, magnificence, reliability, a certain point of honor, it would not be necessary to squeeze his manners with laws, so as not to suppress his virtues. If a character is good in general, what if it has some flaws?
Women could be restrained by laws to improve their manners, and by defining superfluities: but who knows if a certain taste, which would be the source of the Nation's wealth, and that politeness, which is the allure of foreigners, would not disappear?
It is up to the Lawgiver to keep to the spirit of the Nation, when the government is not opposed to the essence, because we never do better than what we freely and in accordance with the natural spirit we do.
Let the Nation's inherently cheerful spirit instill wisdom, nothing you do will benefit you inside or outside. Let him do light things seriously, and serious things merrily.

Polish_1777_ch6.original_text:
Niech nas tak iak iesteśmy zostawią, mowił pewny Szlachcic z Narodu, ktory bardzo podobny do tego iaki wspomnieliśmy dopiero. Natura wszytko naprawia. Wlała nam żywość, która może urażać, y do tego prowadzić, że bardzo biądzić możemy; tę sámę żywość grzeczność ztąd nabyta poprawia, smak nam wzniecaiąc do Świata, a szczegulnie do społeczności Kobiecey.
Niechay nas iak iesteśmy żostawią. Niewiele w sobie złośliwości maiąc, lekkie nasze własności sprawuią że Prawa czyniące przykrość humorowi Towarzyskiemu, niebyłyby przyzwoite bynaymniey.
Polish_1777_ch6.translation:
Let us be left as we are, said a certain Nobleman from the Nation, who was very similar to the one we just mentioned. Nature fixes everything. She has poured into us a vivacity which can offend, and which can lead us to be very afraid; this vivacity improves our taste for the world, and especially for women's society.
Let us be as we are. Having little malice in ourselves, our light properties make that Laws making annoyance to the Society's humor, would not be decent bynaymniey.
